metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
THE BRIGHTON HOTEL
WASHINGTON, D. C.
CALIFORNIA AT CONNECTICUT :: TELEPHONE NORTH 4430
Sunday, December 10, 1944.
Dear Gertie:
We were at Dean Hall a week ago, the only time I have
been there except for five days when I got back in the spring. We
had two days of that beautiful crips early winter weather, cold
except in the sun, when every leaf glistens, the brown grass
is crimson and the smoke from the cabins hung blue against
the pine woods. It made us heartsick not to be able to jump
in a car, run over the Medway from lunch with our neighbours.
Spend the afternoon walking for quail and then return to a
big roaring fire in the gun room and some of Sidney's Old
Fashioneds. Oh, well, some day, some day, perhaps sooner than
we can possibly imagine now. God, how lovely and peaceful
the country seemed. Sidney had felt it too, the few days
he was there, for he seemed to find it surprisingly pleasant
after Paradise Island, once he had faced the silence and
emptyness of the place, and we talked of returning to our
hammocks and our baids [?], letting the days drift, and not
worrying if the roof leaked, the shooting was poor, or the
hawgs got cholera. I did not go to Charleston, but Carola
went down to inspect the houses and found them all standing.
Saw nobody but my parents, who seemed well, older than
three years ago, which is natural. We talked so much
about you. Dean Hall is exactly the same, the house, fires,
food, Tillman and Linda Lee. They are isolated, see scarcely
anyone, seldom leave the place. Vardell has only three able bodies
men, but has accomplished wonders with them, a tractor and a
force of women, holding the wilderness at bay. No country goes
as fast with the wind. Sidney's description of driving up to
Medway was wonderful, in his first vein, true on the whole 
think he found it in good shape. Saw him and Morris
[End Page 1]
a great deal, for they were in and out of the Department all
the time and we had lunch and dinner together several times.
Both of them looked fine. Of course, I got a great about 
wonderful climate, sunshine, vegetation, swimming, all the
set up, but not as much as I had expected, and I personally
wonder if it won't all seem a bit stale after another
session. They seemed to like a bit of bracing fall weather,
if you can ever call this town "bracing." We moved into this
hotel a month ago, from a quaint little house in Georgetwon
where we spent the summer. It had a delightful garden with
some big trees, but when fall came you began to notice
draughts and discover that the furnace and hot water systems
were pretty "quaint" too. So the clanking steam heat of this
hotel feels very good. We have an "apartment" in which we
are [illegible] with our daughter and nurse. The latter cultivates
her voice, undaunted by the fact its volume cries for
Carnegie Hall instead of the cozy dimensions she shares with
us. But we love it - it tells us she is happy and not going
to walk out to a job in the Treasury and leave us to
"mind" Carla. The hotel is a residential hotel, full of
gold braid and stars and arthritic widows. As for war,
nobody give a damn about anything that's happened since
Dewey sailed the seas. I love the soothing atmosphere. My
days are busy enough to pass quickly. We go out quite a
lot, most of it dull as possible, occasional fun, not
much. My life is a week to week affair, always with the
possibility of being sent away again, so I sleep with my
fingers crossed. There is very little news from here to amuse
you. Louise's Kay is back and for good. Heard this from
Huger's wife, Fifi, the other night at Barry's, along with
other N.Y. Talk. Audrey plays bridge all day long, when 
not rainy. Boone is supposedly sold and all the furniture
and [illegible] make of her setting in a very grand new
[End Page 2]
THE BRIGHTON HOTEL
WASHINGTON, D. C.
CALIFORNIA AT CONNECTICUT :: TELEPHONE NORTH 4430
Fifth Avenue apartment. Helen and Avery are off to shoot quail with
George and Jessie today. Bug is here for a good while, which 
is nice, also John and Teddie, Bill and Anne. Gee lives
here with a new, dark and dour looking husband and is sorry
to present him with [illegible] any day now. Nothing that
interests me can I write about, so this is a synthetic letter.
Have to go to N.Y. on business the end of this week for two days.
So may hear something or see somebody to amuse you in
 my next. That city is roaring, although since spring I have
 not seen it except to pass through en route to Carmel three
 or four weekends. But the [illegible] of alien atmosphere do not
 appeal. The theatres sound wonderful, but try to fight your 
 way in. It all seems another world from our surroundings of
 last winter. We think and talk of you constantly. Several people
 I met have seen Sarah -  none recently, but all sounds
 unbelievably, untouchably well. I think she missed a few
 days of joy last spring, but not enough to hurt her game,
 and the hair and nails have never lacked attention and the
 clothes, until recently, came from where they always had
 come. Shall write again before long, now that we have
 learned how. This takes you our very best love.
 Ben.
 [End Page 3]_
